pullRequest.title: Map upgrade doc changes
pullRequest.bodyText:
Testing

Screens Shots

Additional Notes to Reviewer

Release Note

commit.message:
Documentation, update map upgrade document

Prune, consolidate, simplify

nodes.bodyText: As I said, here it is not clear whether the mentioned properties are the properties within the game file or the properties files of the map. Assuming that "TripleA Game XML properties and options" means the properties and options within the game (XML) file, this is not correct, as this "list of changes" is not only about that. That also would imply that this list of changes is useless for upgrading mapskins, while it actually contains information critical for such maps too.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1,35 +1,26 @@
 # How To Upgrade Legacy Map Features
 
-A list of (case sensitive) changes to upgrade legacy TripleA Game XML properties and options
-to the most recent.
+A list of changes to upgrade legacy TripleA Game XML properties and options to the most recent.

nodes.bodyText:
I assume you assume that the "*" symbol is itself meaningful enough for everyone that there is no need to explain it means something like "zero or more of any characters". If so, I tend not to agree. I believe that a code like
<triplea minimumVersion="*"/>:<triplea minimumVersion="1.9.0.0"/>
should better have an explanation about the fact that the original "minimumVersion" value can be whatever.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1,35 +1,26 @@
 # How To Upgrade Legacy Map Features
 
-A list of (case sensitive) changes to upgrade legacy TripleA Game XML properties and options
-to the most recent.
+A list of changes to upgrade legacy TripleA Game XML properties and options to the most recent.
  
-When changes are required, all occurrences of the code before the `>>` must be substituted
-with the code after the `>>`. In any code, the "\*" symbol means whatever (the change or deletion is
-to be applied to every given code having whatever character or characters in place of the "\*").

nodes.bodyText: If you completely remove every reference of the TripleA versions from which and to which to upgrade, I assume this can only mean this is for upgrading every map feature. Meaning that someone having a map made for TripleA 1.0 should be able to upgrade it to TripleA 2.2 by following the instruction in this document. Even in this case, I would make explicit that the starting point is TripleA 1.0. In any case, since, as far as I can tell, this document is still seemingly about 1.8.0.9 to 1.9.0.0.3266 upgrades only, I would keep such reference until it is correct or, at the very least, clarifying that this document is an incomplete "work-in-progress", making very clear that people should not currently expect it giving full information for upgrading to the latest whatever map they may have (because I can see it is certainly not able to assure that).
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1,35 +1,26 @@
 # How To Upgrade Legacy Map Features
 
-A list of (case sensitive) changes to upgrade legacy TripleA Game XML properties and options
-to the most recent.
+A list of changes to upgrade legacy TripleA Game XML properties and options to the most recent.
  
-When changes are required, all occurrences of the code before the `>>` must be substituted
-with the code after the `>>`. In any code, the "\*" symbol means whatever (the change or deletion is
-to be applied to every given code having whatever character or characters in place of the "\*").
-
-## Upgrade from 1.8.0.9 to 1.9.0.0.3266

nodes.bodyText: This should have not been removed. Since the document is not informing how to upgrade such items, I think it is good having a mention telling that such items are not covered by the information given. For example, if one has a map with a trigger changing the value of "giveUnitControl" from false to true, that item will not be touched, by following the information at this documentation literally (it would be needed manually to delete the whole trigger, since the option is useless both at the "true" and at the "false" values, thus the trigger is useless too). I decided not to provided such information as the case is remote, and merely noticing that "Property" options are not touched (to avoid confusion, I'll point out that property options are not properties (the term "property" in TripleA means at least three different and largely unrelated things, as far as I know)).
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1,35 +1,26 @@
 # How To Upgrade Legacy Map Features
 
-A list of (case sensitive) changes to upgrade legacy TripleA Game XML properties and options
-to the most recent.
+A list of changes to upgrade legacy TripleA Game XML properties and options to the most recent.
  
-When changes are required, all occurrences of the code before the `>>` must be substituted
-with the code after the `>>`. In any code, the "\*" symbol means whatever (the change or deletion is
-to be applied to every given code having whatever character or characters in place of the "\*").
-
-## Upgrade from 1.8.0.9 to 1.9.0.0.3266
-
-Note: The following list covers all basic upgrade cases for maps, but it may not upgrade "Property"
-options (playerProperty, unitProperty...) of ineffective items you must delete (such changes have
-been omitted from this document for brevity).

nodes.bodyText: The reason why I created two "special code" sections is that such changes touch items that are very rarely found in games. Practically, only games having triggers changing values of options may need making such changes. Maybe the "so you probably don't have these within the game file" note could have been clarified by explaining that games with no triggers don't need having these changes applied to them (even though games with triggers are unlikely to have them too). Consolidating all in a single section is a reasonable preference, but this means having a lot of changes code that is very rarely useful, thus my preference of splitting between common and uncommon changes to make.

nodes.bodyText: This item, or any item, should better not stay in the middle of the "reset" and "non-reset" version of the code for turning the "isTwoHit" option value to true (the "reset" is a redundant coding, since the option accepts only one value, but it cannot be exclude a game might have it).

nodes.bodyText: You previously removed a "were already deprecated" reference. I suggest either removing all or none of them. Also saying that "did nothing" is meaningless in the moment it is not documented when (this was supposed to mean "did nothing in 1.8.0.9", that being the referenced starting point).

nodes.bodyText:
This whole section has been removed without a valid substutite, so it is now a missing item, thus needs to be added back. To clarify, what this section was doing, was telling that if having a code like
game_start=classical/game_start/game_start_02_gladiator_entrance.wav
within the "sounds" properties file, the code has to be changed to
game_start=classical/game_start/game_start_02_gladiator_entrance.mp3.
This is not even necessarily related to the "sounds" folder, as, in the example, we are referencing code in the TripleA "assets" folder.

nodes.bodyText: Since, as explained, all changes that follow are not additional changes, but merely "unnecessary additional information", I believe this "More XML Changes" entry is confusing or even wrongly descriptive (since from this point onwards there are no more changes of any kind, just alternative ones and additional information).

nodes.bodyText: This line used to be before the information about changing the format of the sound files. The "non-code" items mentioned were only the needed change of substituting all "wav" files with "mp3" ones, which is now detailed before this line. I believe everything else are code changes. So this line does not make any sense to me (I don't get what are these "non-code" items, now). Moreover, since a section break follows, it seems to me that this is even saying the "non-code items" part is empty.

nodes.bodyText: Assuming that all changes are supposed to be case sensitive (something that used to be explicitly stated) changing "attatchment" to "attachment" is a different change from changing "Attatchment" to "Attachment", so what follows are not procedural alternatives to changing "attatchment" to "attachment", thus the information now given is wrong.
